ALLEGATION:
The agency has not submitted records to Michigan Department of Health and
Human Services (MDHHS) for permanent retention one year following the final order
of adoption as required. There are two records that have not been submitted.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/23/2022 I reviewed the complaint, and contact was made with the complainant
via email by my Peer Consultant. I made initial contact with the agency about the
complaint via email on 5/24/2022.
On 5/25/2022, Adoption Departmental Manager (ADM) X provided information about
the complaint to me, and a Peer Consultant, via email. She reported her department
had been in contact with agencies about their closed adoption records. ADM X
reported the department had inquired with the agencies as to the status of the
closed adoption files requested. Her department found that these files either had not
been submitted to the local office at all or were submitted outside the required
timeframe of 12 to 13 months following finalization. ADM X listed two finalized
adoption files for Catholic Charities of Southeastern Michigan that may not have
been submitted.
ADM X provided clarity on how the files are to be closed and sent to the County
Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) offices, and the DHS-788 form
to be attached on the closed file boxes. Additionally, ADM X provided information
with respect to if an agency still has old closed adoption records outside the ones on
the list provided related to the complaint; and what that agency should do with those
records. Whether those closed records should come to ADM X’s office or the
County DHHS Office. ADM X reported, when R400.12713 was updated in 2015,
agencies were instructed to send their backlogged adoption records directly to
Central Office. She reported, it has been seven years and at this point agencies
should be caught up, and on schedule to send closed records to the local offices
between 12-13 months following finalization. If an agency still has old closed
adoption records, her office will work with the agency, accept those old records, so
as to not have the local county office bombarded with old records. She advised it
would be very helpful if the agency would include in any corrective action plan the
agency’s plan to ensure that Lansing/the department gets those old records.
On 5/24/2022, via telephone, and 6/9/2022 via onsite visit, I interviewed Chief
Administrator A about the complaint. Chief Administrator A also provided
information via email on 5/25/2022. Chief Administrator A reported the agency has a
number of closed foster care and adoption records which have yet to be submitted to
the department. She reported the agency has 26 closed adoption cases from 2020
3

and approximately 26 from 2021 which are pending submission to the department.
The two closed adoption records connected to this complaint, Child 1’s and Child
2’s, would be included in the former group. She reported no one had requested
these two specific records; that the agency had not received an email or letter
advising to submit these two records by a specific deadline. She provided a
“Record Retention Verification form showing the submission of Child 1’s, Child 2’s
(adoptions finalized 10/23/2020 and 10/30/2020 respectively) and 26 other closed
records to DHHS- North Central on 5/31/2022. Thirteen of those cases were closed
adoption cases; five of those had adoption finalization dates over one year (ranging
from 5/19/2019-6/15/2020). Six others had adoption finalization dates in
2021(ranging from 4/5/2021- 5/25/2021) and one was finalized on 4/21/2022.
Chief Administrator A reported the agency also has more than a hundred other
closed adoption records, which are ready for submission to the department, where
the adoption finalizations range between 2015- 2020. These records have not yet
been sent. There are also hundreds of other older adoption closed records for 2014
or older that they are working to box up (these are a mixture of domestic and foster
care adoptive cases). She reported there was some uncertainty as to where those
closed cases were to go. She said, Lansing will only take 50 boxes at a time.
Additionally, that there had been the question of what a closed adoption record
should consists of. Thus, clarity was needed on this so that their agency would get
the file content correct; and not have the closed record rejected. The latter of which
Chief Administrator A reported was implied, given remarks reported related to prior
files submitted. She reported reaching out to the department, inclusive of ADM X
and State Adoption Analyst (SAA)T in 2021 related to transferring 160 boxes of
closed records, because the agency was moving in August of 2021. I provided
information to Chief Administrator A that ADM X shared with me about the content
requirement for closed adoption records, and where current closed, and older closed
adoption records should go, some of which I mentioned earlier in this report.
During my onsite visit I observed the agency’s secure storage for their closed
records. I addressed the agency future compliance plan. Chief Administrator A
reported the plan going forward to maintain compliance is that they will maintain a
spreadsheet related to adoption finalization dates and adoption case closure
submissions. Currently they are reaching out to each County DHHS office related to
scheduling a drop off for finalized adoption files. They plan to have all outstanding
adoption files dropped off by the end of July. Once they are current, they plan to
submit the closed adoption files off on a monthly cycle, and to track them via their
spreadsheet and Records Retention Verification form.
Reviewed
 A copy of an adoption file record’s list from Adoption Departmental Manager X,
as referenced earlier in this report.
 A copy of a Record’s Retention Verification document showing 28 named records
were submitted to DHHS-North Central, as referenced earlier in this report.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12713 Adoption placement record.
(5) The Michigan department of human services must
permanently retain all adoption records for children
adopted from Michigan's child welfare system. The
adoption agency must forward any adoption records for
children adopted from the Michigan child welfare system to
the department one year after finalization of the adoption.
The adoption agency may not retain the original copies or
any other copies of the adoption records.
ANALYSIS: Child 1’s and Child 2’s adoptions were finalized on 10/23/2020
and 10/30/2020 respectively. These two records were submitted
to the department on 5/31/2022, more than the 12-13 months
timeframe required by the department.
Additionally, the agency has numerous other finalized adoption
records which are beyond the 12–13-month submission
timeframe, which the agency has yet to submit to the
department.
The agency is in violation of the rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, continuation of the agency’s
current licensing status is recommended.

sir_summary.summary: The investigation found that Catholic Charities of Southeast Michigan failed to submit adoption records to the state department within the required one-year timeframe after finalization, specifically identifying two children whose records were submitted over a year late and acknowledging a backlog of hundreds of unsubmitted records dating back years. The agency cited confusion over submission procedures and content requirements, but had not maintained compliance with the clear rule. The agency is directly culpable for the systemic failure to ensure timely submission of these permanent records as required by licensing rules.

sir_violation_level.justification: The substantiated violation is solely the failure to submit closed adoption records to the state department within the required 12-13 month timeframe. This is an administrative paperwork and record retention issue, aligning with the 'Low SIRs' category for 'Administrative or paperwork issues: missing signatures... minor documentation errors, late submission of a report...'
